reporting_cycle: Secretary-General reports prior to the expiration of the mandate
summary:
Here is a clear and concise summary of the Security Council document:

The Security Council adopted Resolution 1542 (2004) on April 30, 2004, recalling previous resolutions and welcoming the report of the Secretary-General. The Council:

* Affirms its commitment to Haiti's sovereignty, independence, territorial integrity, and unity.
* Deplores human rights violations and urges the Transitional Government to ensure the promotion and protection of human rights.
* Welcomes efforts to sensitize peacekeeping personnel to HIV/AIDS and other communicable diseases.

The Council establishes the United Nations Stabilization Mission in Haiti (MINUSTAH) for an initial period of six months, with the intention to renew for further periods.

* MINUSTAH will have a civilian and military component, consisting of up to 1,622 civilian police and 6,700 troops.
* The military component will report directly to the Special Representative through the force commander.

The Council requests:

* The Secretary-General to appoint a Special Representative with overall authority on the ground for the coordination and conduct of all UN activities in Haiti.
* MINUSTAH to cooperate and coordinate with the OAS and CARICOM.

Under Chapter VII of the Charter, MINUSTAH's mandate includes:

* Securing a stable environment to support the Transitional Government and constitutional process.
* Assisting the Transitional Government in monitoring, restructuring, and reforming the Haitian National Police.
* Assisting with disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration.

The Council also:
* Supports the establishment of a Core Group to facilitate MINUSTAH's mandate and promote interaction with Haitian authorities.
* Urges all parties to work towards a broad political consensus on the nature and duration of the political transition.
The Security Council, 
Reaffirming its commitment to the sovereignty, independence, and territorial integrity of Haiti, 
1. Decides to establish a Multinational Interim Force (MIF) to facilitate the creation of a secure environment for the provision of humanitarian assistance and to assist in the maintenance of security in Haiti; 

II. Mandate 

The mandate of MIF shall include 
DDR programmes 
weapons control 
public security 
rule of law 
protection of civilians 

III. Tasks 

 Tasks shall include 
support to Haitian National Police 
restoration of public order 
protection of UN personnel 
promotion of human rights
